questions.question: What is a writ of mandamus?

choices.answer: A written request that the Supreme Court review a decision
The practice of using the basis of past decisions to determine future cases
An order from the Court requiring someone to perform a lawful duty
The official power to make legal decisions
The rights that a person has when they are in police custody
Willingness of a judge to overturn laws and precedence
The belief that judges should stand with earlier court decisions
The official power to make legal decisions

questions.question: What is described in Article III of the Constitution?

choices.answer: The role and format of the Supreme Court
The role of the President
The role and format of Congress
The rights of citizens, also known as the Bill of Rights

questions.question: What is the principle of stare decisis?

choices.answer: Judges should base their decisions on the outcomes of past cases
Judges should use their power to overturn laws that seem unjust
Congress should have the power to create federal courts
Judges should focus on how a law applies instead of overturning it

questions.question: Brown v. Board of Education is an example of judicial activism.

choices.answer: True
False
The law that created the federal court system
The belief that judges should limit their power over legislation
The authority to hear a case before any other court
The power of the Supreme Court to decide if a law is constitutional or not

questions.question: In cases of judicial activism, judges rely only on the decisions of past cases.

choices.answer: True
False
The US President who appointed several judges right before he left office
The Chief Justice whose ruling gave the Court the power of judicial review
The US President who did not finalize the appointment of the new judges
The Secretary of State who did not send the judges' letters of appointment
The official power to make legal decisions
The belief that judges should limit their power over legislation
The law that created the federal court system
Willingness of a judge to overturn laws and precedence

questions.question: What did the Judiciary Act of 1789 do?

choices.answer: Gave people in police custody the right to remain silent
Gave the Supreme Court the power to decide if a law is constitutional
Created the federal court system
Decided that Marbury was right and Madison should have sent the letters
